1.author: Regular_Mouse2003
1.body:
>See title of this Reddit.

Yup, it's:

>What people do not consider priviledge but it is?

And you have asserted that:

>To think you have a difficult life while living in a first world country

is a privilege. 

​

So...do you think the only way someone can think they have a difficult life in a first-world country is due to privilege? Or are there actually people in first-world countries living a difficult life?

I really can't imagine the world you've lived in where you've never seen someone in a first-world country struggling or living a difficult life. Guess all those homeless veterans are just too privileged for their own good, and/or they're just beneath your notice.

>And now just go away

Why? There's literally nothing stopping you from doing so. Are my words offending you?

5.author: Xirdus
5.body:
1. Don't worry about this one. You're on a good path right now. All you need to do is wait.

2. Same as 1 (and closely tied to it). It's a matter of time.

3. 10 dates before death? Why not. 10 dates this year? It's a very bad goal to have - it will suck out fun from all these dates. Instead, be on the lookout for this one girl but no pressure.

4. This is a very bad goal to have. It offers zero improvement in life, and occupies space that could be taken by something more worthwhile. In extreme case, you might become addicted to the feeling of achievement and your whole life will revolve around low effort useless goals (this is video game addiction in nutshell).

5.author: onetruelink
5.body:
I've sort of been trying to identify skills I have and would need. My internship offers trainings and I've been looking into a few, and I've had my resume re-written to show off some existing skills. And I am trying to aim at some specific industries (namely gov work). But I could probably be doing a bit more in those regards to trying and seek out more info in regards to what I could learn, like learning how to get a security clearance would def help me in the areas I wanna do work in. 

And to expand a bit on the other goals, admittedly I have been going more CV rather than setting more immediate deadlines for things I wanna do for them

5.author: onetruelink
5.body: Thank you, this is is really helpful. I've been doing some work with the process but not as much as I probably should've. I'll definitely start thinking about specific, short term things I can do that can further these along

5.author: onetruelink
5.body: I think this is what I've been lacking here- tok focused on the end state and not breaking things up more. I'm going to try and make my goals a bit more manageable by having mini goals to go for. TY for the response!

9.author: AccomplishedToe-TA
9.body:
You’re the only one arguing about what a break is my dude.

What I’m saying to him is ‘you get x amount of hours a day to go outside and and do mindless crap while you smoke, that’s more than most fathers get’ and he’s looking at me like I’m high. That’s the issue.

The hour or two he is available to look after the baby each day, I am trying to prioritising working, running errands, showering, tidying the house, etc. I get he can’t give me more time, because there’s not enough hours in the day. So I just don’t get any ‘relax time’ at the moment.

I accept that’s just how it has to be for me at the moment. But don’t fucking complain to me about how you don’t get enough relax time or don’t have time to do anything when I have none.

9.author: davidmacku
9.body: Okay. Good look. You ain’t gonna get what you need from him. What you say is mindless crap for him is his break. Over and out. You ain’t gonna get what you need. You ain’t listening.

9.author: AccomplishedToe-TA
9.body:
Sure it’s his break. It IS mindless crap. Mindless crap is a great stress relief, I’m not dismissing that. Yep it’s his break. Totally agree.

All ‘I need’ from him is to stop thinking a total of 2-4 hours a day is not enough and that I’m wrong when I say most fathers do not get that much. That was the entire point of my post… to ask what other men get.

I’m not sure what valuable insights you think you’re offering that I’m not listening to.

9.author: davidmacku
9.body:
You are too concerned with being correct about his mindless time wasting. You gotta reframe it to get what you want. Nagging him about mindless time is not gonna get the extra hours of assistance you would like.

What other men get is not your concern. That gives you extra things to nag about. You need to get what you want by being direct and non-nagging. Using language like mindless time etc, ain’t gonna get you what you want.

9.author: AccomplishedToe-TA
9.body:
Are you even reading what I say? Or are you inventing your own scenarios? I don’t nag him about it at all. He complains about not getting enough. I respond to his complaints by pointing out he actually gets quite a lot of time.

Im not looking for extra ‘assistance’. I’m not looking for anything other than for him to stop complaining and feeling sorry for himself. Where did you get nagging from? Are you projecting here?

9.author: davidmacku
9.body: So he complains that he hasn’t got enough down time, and you think he does? So you are not asking for more time to assist with the baby?

9.author: AccomplishedToe-TA
9.body:
Exactly. No I’m not asking him for more help with the baby. As I said earlier, there is no more time. I’d love him to take the baby more so I could have some mindless crap time myself. But I completely accept that there is no extra time for him to do this because when he has the baby, I have stuff to do. I do not blame him for this part.

100% my issue is that he complains and feels hard done by because he doesn’t get enough time for himself. And I think that it’s completely reasonable that I don’t want to hear it when I get no time at all (which I’ve acknowledged isn’t his fault).

9.author: davidmacku
9.body:
Okay, here is what you do: 
1. Write down for a week all of your daily activities in slots of 1 hour or 30 minutes. Then compare notes on where your time is going and how you can be more deliberative about work, baby, leisure, household duties, etc. Then try to work on how you use your time more wisely next week. You can both optimise leisure and baby time, and try to optimise work/household chores.

16.author: SeaofBloodRedRoses
16.body:
Yeah, so you read that number 2?

**aversion** being another word for extreme discomfort or strong dislike, explaining discomfort phobias and also hatred phobias.

**intolerance** also being why words like homophobia and transphobia exist.

16.author: Unable_Duty7809
16.body:
And again none apply.  I'm not interested in dating a trans person.  I'm not intolerant of them, I wish them well.  I don't dislike them or have discomfort around them, I simply don't react sexually to them at all and they are more or less invisible to me in that regard.

I totally support their right to live their lives, pursue happiness as they define it and to live safely and without fear and would certainly vote in elections to that effect.

But stop with the bullying trying to label my lack of interest as some sort of less-than on my part.

16.author: SeaofBloodRedRoses
16.body:
Who the fuck did you think you were replying to? r/lostredditors much?? All I said was that your definition of phobia was incorrect and incomplete, so you cited a dictionary that proved me right. That's literally it, that's all we said. I never tried to pin a label to you, I literally just corrected your English.

But that aside, if you're refusing to date a trans person for no other reason than they happen to be trans, then yes, you're transphobic.

16.author: Unable_Duty7809
16.body: I'm not replying to anyone of significance and as I pointed out... no you weren't right.

16.author: SeaofBloodRedRoses
16.body:
Here's the last line of your comment. The line that irrefutably proves I'm right when I say phobia doesn't exclusively mean fear.

> 2: intolerance or aversion for

There's really nothing to debate there, you literally quoted a source that proved you wrong lmfao, you even included the specific line in your comment.

16.author: Unable_Duty7809
16.body:

I wish you well with your sex change.

16.author: SeaofBloodRedRoses

18.author: JustHankerton
18.body:
Would you like links to medical studies or personal experience from myself and others in the EMS and nursing community.

We have to ask specifically about gender vs sex because of specific biological induced complication that come from a specific sex. Which is not at all linked to a transgender patient's gender.

18.author: davidmacku
18.body: Not interested, this is a complete different discussion.

18.author: JustHankerton
18.body: How so? Because one is medically recognized and the other is a political debate over other people's bodily autonomy?

18.author: davidmacku
18.body: No because my original argument was that gender is not a social construct. Medical practices dealing with transgender persons, is not socially constructed gender, but medical interventions to allow someone to present as another gender. Medical interventions are not social constructions.

18.author: JustHankerton
18.body:
You stated gender=sex, which is false. Medically that is false, socially its whatever politics you watch. 

Your beliefs are certainly your own to choose. Just know that there are fields outside of the humanities that have conducted extensive peer reviewed studies that have concluded otherwise.

18.author: davidmacku
18.body: False. In every natural language on the planet sex and gender are synonymous apart from in sociology text books and people dealing with transgender issues. Goodbye. This conversation is over as we will not see eye to eye.

19.author: Greymalkyn76
19.body:
I feel like parts of this are my own story.  I'd known this girl for years but never really got to know her or spent much time with her.  For one reason or another, we ended up talking more and next thing I knew we were in this whirlwind relationship.  It was mostly long distance, but we were making it work with regular visits, face time, etc.  It was amazing and then it wasn't.

It started small, with things like while playing a game online together with her suddenly becoming someone else and berating me for making a mistake.  Then guilt tripping if I went to hang out with a friend instead of face timing 24/7.  Then came the gaslighting and blackmail.

I kept telling myself that I could handle it and that it was just her BPD, and deep down she did love me because when she was fine, it was incredible and that was the real her.  So I would endure the abuse, the verbal beratements, the stories that made no sense and felt like they were told to make me feel bad, the lies.  I convinced myself that even though half the time I found myself curled up in bed crying because of it that I could handle it for her.

The last straw for me was when we had plans to visit and they got cancelled because she couldn't get the time off from work.  I said I was fine with it and I would do things around her apartment while she worked, but she refused and said it wasn't fair.  And when that week came that we were supposed to be together, all communication stopped.  Found out she was taking a trip to see a friend elsewhere but for some reason didn't want me to know.

She called about 4 years ago (after 2 years of not hearing from her) to see how I was doing "without her" and hoped that I had someone who could comfort me through the loss.

19.author: tallcountry68
19.body: I feel for you, she’s sounds like a classic narcissist with sociopathic/psychopathic traits. I would bet she had a traumatic childhood.

19.author: Greymalkyn76
19.body:
100%, or so she said.  I did know that her mother lived with a boyfriend in a halfway house and her father was pretty much a redneck (though other than that was a good guy).  When her parents separated, she was raised by her grandmother who seemed like one of the sweetest people I've met but to hear her tell about it she was a tyrant and a glorified jailer.


Broken home, raised in a situation she didn't want to be on, absent mother and father.  A big part of it why I stayed as long as I did is because I was sure that I could be the good point in her life.

19.author: tallcountry68
19.body:
Almost a carbon copy of my 23 year train wreck. Mine was treated harshly by her dad(beat with electric cord), mom constantly calling her fat, she left home at 16, on the streets. Got into drugs and alcohol early.
One failed previous marriage with 3 kids, told me he was a serial cheater. Found out later that is was the other way around. Classic behavior for a sociopathic narcissist. They will accuse you of exactly what they are doing. The unveiling of my monster didn’t come until she got a windfall of money through her family. She barely worked at all in 23 years, so when she got the money, I was expendable. They will use you for whatever they need, until they don’t.
Read up on narcissism, sociopath/psychopath and mine had hyper sexuality and opioid addiction.

Knowledge is power, mainly you have to recognize that it didn’t have anything to do with you, it’s just how they are.

Wish you well, brother

22.author: rewq657
22.body: Yeah that's what I need to do. I just gotta learn to cook things. Macaroni and cheese is always easy though 🤣

22.author: connoratchley2
22.body: If you like steaks I really like to expect with how I cook them, I can get like 5 for the price of one meal at Texas Roadhouse, baked potatoes are so easy to cook on the grill or just in the microwave. Macaroni and cheese smacks though so I don’t blame you at all I had that at work today 😂

22.author: rewq657
22.body: Yeah my grandpa gave me his venison steak recipe but I have yet to try to make it, it's fire when he does it though so I hope I can make it right lol

23.author: PerspectivePure2169
23.body:
Money grows from the ground in farming. 

But oh do you earn it 😄

23.author: Treepocalypse
23.body: Trees grow out of the ground hombre

23.author: Treepocalypse
23.body:
Man, I’m sorry. I took that the wrong way. There’s another thread going and this guy there is an idiot and I reacted instead of responded to your comment. 

Farming is super hard, important, gratifying work and you are awesome for sharing that with me. I hope you harvest all the money out of the earth.

23.author: PerspectivePure2169
23.body: No worries man, appreciate that and appreciate you, have a good one 👍

24.author: darkriverofshadows
24.body:
Well, I try to keep my mental health in check, but that's about it. Not a lot of sense in trying to build a career in situation where company you work for may be bombed out of existence. Around autumn I was looking for a job, and one of the options was a job is office near railway station. I went for interview in sunday, and in 9 am on monday office was destroyed. Hopefully I'm not ignoring air raid siren, so I wasn't there, but after that I look only for working from home options, and for now even those are problematic, as we have regular electricity shutdowns. 4-5 hours, then 4 hours shutdown, and so on. 

And yeah, I know that this shitshow should end closer to the end of the summer, but at this point I just stopped even thinking about my plans for life, at least until war ends. Surviving and spending as much time as possible with people I care about is enough for now

24.author: AmericanGoldenJackal
24.body: You might be able to solve your power problems especially if you can work together. You'll have to do your own power gen locally. It depends on what materials and resources you have access too. Something like a river or creek makes that easy

24.author: darkriverofshadows
24.body: In my case it's not exactly a good option for a multitude of reasons, first of all - I live in apartment, so generator isn't exactly a good idea, it's a giant pain in the ass to connect it to apartments network, and it's loud, smelly, and even if I can put up with it, my neighbors might have different opinions on the matter. Second - generators cost went sky-high for obvious reasons, and fuel costs quite a sum too. Same for charging stations. In situation where I get like less than 500 bucks per month, I can't exactly say that I can allow it. More so, I already adapted to irregular shutdowns, my work allows me to work in offline too, and I already have a laptop that lasts exactly as long as average shutdown. In case of actual blackouts, well, my group of friends already has a plan specifically for such situation.

24.author: AmericanGoldenJackal
24.body:
You're telling me what you don't have access to. 

What do you have access to? If there is a river, for example, your building could set up a trompe and use compressed air to run generators. Even salvaged electrical motors. That might get you a few circuits for the building. 

You're already spending your free time with the people you care about. You might be able to improve your situation a little here or there.

24.author: darkriverofshadows
24.body: I live in a high-rise building that is a) around 5 km from closest river, b) in a middle of the stone jungle, c) technically every change like that is supposed to be coordinated with building company, and representative of those fuckers ran away as soon as possible, so contacting them isnt an option. basically anything that requires modifying building or making changes in electric wiring, even minor ones like setting retranslator(not sure if its the right term, english isnt my main language) that gives electricity as soon as main source of power stops is a no-go. only viable options are either appliable to private houses only (which is plan b that I mentioned before) or generator with charging station. I studied this question to know my options, but thanks for caring anyway

24.author: AmericanGoldenJackal
24.body: They ran away? I guess there is no one to stop you.

25.author: Birdsongsoul
25.body: I never get mad like that. I wonder where all that power goes.

25.author: KitFan2020
25.body: What would you do if you met them again? Would you say something?

25.author: KitFan2020
25.body: Don’t look back, look ahead. Be the kind of brother you want to be.

25.author: KitFan2020
25.body: It must have been very hard for those on the receiving end but people understand more than you think…

25.author: KitFan2020
25.body:
This has made me think about the teenagers I work with every day. Some are so angry and lash out at every opportunity - at teachers, other students, even their friends. 

I tell them that it takes a lot of courage to be kind to others when it feels like the whole world is against them. They’re potentially opening themselves to more rejection and more pain… I tell them to see if they can find the courage to try it and see what happens. 
I’m basically telling them that I care, other people care. Not everyone but most people. They get it…

25.author: KitFan2020
25.body:
Haha! Yes, I was definitely the chubby girl at school. 
I wouldn’t say I’m exactly slim now (30 + years later) but a bit of weight is great as you get older - no wrinkles, smooth skin, good hair…
He knows who I am - we have mutual friends but I haven’t seen him in 30 years.
He said ‘Hello (my name)’ and promptly looked like he was going to pass out. Embarrassed? Maybe. I don’t know!

25.author: KitFan2020
25.body:
‘Pretend nice guy’ is worse than ‘Upfront mean guy’! No woman likes the former.

Some women like the bad boy image and actively seek out emotionally stunted men. Some  even think they can change them believing that there is a great guy hidden in there somewhere. 
Sometimes they’re right and the person is worth the effort, sometimes they’re wrong.

26.author: Frequent_Composer_62
26.body: A lot of these schemes rely on people feeling embarrassed. Gyms in particular because you try to talk to people about it and you get scared they might laugh and say "Why did you even sign up if you never go?"

26.author: lifesyndrome
26.body:
yah I already have a dumbbell and I'm just gonna do running from here on out cuz this is annoying 

last time this happened the guys working there tried to make an excuse and say "it's like insurance, that's why we're charging" 

took so much energy to not cuss him out

26.author: lifesyndrome
26.body: do u think u can make a lawsuit out of this?

27.author: Blue_Note991
27.body: I think you might be future me. Pray for us.

27.author: BadLifeChoicesPNW
27.body:
How so? You're doubting your intuition and staying in a bad relationship? 

FWIW I got divorced. One of the best life choices I ever made.

27.author: Blue_Note991
27.body: I'm involved with a woman who is perpetually unhappy and has serious mental health issues. Nowhere near marriage and often I think I'd be better off without her, but I am pretty hung up on her still.

27.author: BadLifeChoicesPNW
27.body:
Trust your intuition.

The energy and dedication and loving that you have shown by staying with your current partner, despite everything she is going through, will be appreciated a million times more by so many other women out there.

Leading up to and following my divorce I got into therapy to own my half of what went wrong and make sure that I was in a good place going forward. It wasn't until then that I eventually learned my ex-wife has BPD.

I sincerely hope you find the strength and resolve to take care of yourself and create some space from the woman you're currently involved with. You probably need to cut her off completely.

The answer to this question will tell you all you need to know. Have you ever felt or has she ever made you feel like if you just did something, whatever, even something that seems small. If you did that, then she would be happy?

27.author: Blue_Note991
27.body:
Thanks for the encouraging words my man. I was with someone for 5 years who had BPD so you have my deepest sympathies. They can be an absolute nightmare.

I dont think the current girl does but she does have PTSD and major depression. She also is from a dysfunctional family and has really bad conflict resolution. I was honest with her about some things she did I didnt like and she has been in a depressive episode ever since. And I dont think shes exaggerating, her psychiatrist had to adjust her meds and she cancelled her birthday.

This has gone on for weeks and we've barely spoken since I am not apologizing for saying how I felt. She even said I said so in a kind and respectful way. But I fear myself going back to her if she tries to mend that bridge. Despite all her flaws I do really love spending time with her. But i need to find the strength to walk away for good.

28.author: Blue_Js_are_okay
28.body:
He wasn't a good person, used to hit my mom until she left him, was always in and out of jail or substance abusing, and was a narcissist.

Admittedly I wasn't a good kid, I became a pretty rebellious teenager and sometimes a disobedient brat. Not the kind you see on Dr. Phil, more like I just wanted to stay out with friends all the time and sometimes we'd get into trouble.

So eventually we had a falling out, said some unkind things to each other then he said no one wants me around and to get out and not come back, and so.

28.author: lostbutnotalone1
28.body: I see. What do you mean “no one wants you around”? I’m guessing it wasn’t just you and your dad alone together? Also how come your mom didn’t leave with you? And are you still in contact with your mom?

28.author: Blue_Js_are_okay
28.body: It was my father, his gf and my 3 siblings. My mom moved across the country about 5 years prior. She passed away last year

28.author: lostbutnotalone1
28.body: Damn dude. That’s about broken as a family can get. Sorry to hear about that. Did you go to her funeral

28.author: Blue_Js_are_okay
28.body:
It's all good, one day I will have a family and I'll make sure things don't turn out this way for them.

And yes I did

28.author: lostbutnotalone1
28.body: Did your dad attend the funeral

29.author: tebanano
29.body: Priorities, right? Also, It’s not all or nothing. Part time is an option.

29.author: stonky808
29.body: I literally posted the exact same thing. Also my wife does work part time. No matter wth you say you aren’t going to convince me that working because you want to when you don’t have to while your baby sits at daycare for 6-8 hours a day isn’t a selfish asf move.

29.author: tebanano
29.body: Exactly.

29.author: tebanano
29.body: Sure, but it’s kinda weird you’re giving women shit for doing the same as you: It doesn’t seem like you prioritized your kids over your work.

29.author: stonky808
29.body: No, I’m not actually. I’m giving people shit that throw their baby into daycare for 6-8 hrs a day when they don’t have to be  because they rather be at work and not “giving up their careers”. THAT is what I am saying is selfish and everyone is coming up with “what ifs”. Bottom of one of the parents makes enough money where the other can go part time or stay home and they refuse, and toss baby in daycare…..SELFISH ASF.

29.author: tebanano
29.body:
For some people, it’s too risky to fully rely on only one income. Sure, you can live with one income, until that income ends because of layoffs, illness, or worse.

You’re choosing to see selfishness. You want to feel good about your own decision by putting down other parents who chose differently.

You’re judging women for making the same personal choices as **you**.
Using your own words: “[you] WILL NOT GOVE UP OR REDICE YOUR HOURS because you have a baby”.

29.author: stonky808
29.body:
Again, excuses. And again I’ll repeat myself. FOR PEOPLE THAT ARE. ABLE. TO. DO. SO. BUT. REFUSE. because they don’t want to stop working or give up their career. AND LIKE I SAID 5 times already, I’ll gladly be a stay at home dad if my wife wanted to go to work and be a high income earner, but she doesn’t…..she’s rather spend her free time with the children she gave birth to. 

Before you post again, please read my posts so I don’t have to keep repeating myself.

29.author: tebanano
29.body:
> Again, excuses.

Yeah, just like you are using excuses to justify not being at home with your kids, working 50+ hours instead of being a father. You keep justifying yourself and judging others.

29.author: stonky808
29.body:
So coming home every day after 8 hrs but working 2 16hr shifts a week is not being a father? Lol

Like I said, excuses. Me and my wife spent a massive amount of time with our toddlers/pre preschool kids. They all knew basic penmanship and phonetic decoding by the time they were 3/4 years old in preschool. All attended prestigious private institutions for grade school and scored in the top 90%+ on kindergarten entry testing in language arts and mathematics. 

It’s almost like you get out what you put in. I posted what I posted in here in askwomen subreddit and was banned. Also, ALL the info any parent needs to teach their young child ANYTHING and EVERYTHING is available free online. But most would rather spend time on Facebook and instagram.

29.author: tebanano
29.body: I’m just judging you by the same measure you judge others: You could be spending _more_ time with your kids, prioritizing them over long work hours. Working and coming home is not something to brag about regarding fatherhood.

29.author: stonky808
29.body:
Um compared to having my babies/toddlers in daycare 6-8hrs a day? Lol. Like I said and I’ll say it again…..

My wife and I have spent an enormous amount of time with our children. We taught them penmanship and phonetic decoding from a very early age 3 years old. By the time they were in preschool our children could basic read and write. They all attended prestigious grade schools and scores 90%+ percentiles in language arts and math in kindergarten entrance exam testing. Now, that take TIME and DEDICATION to you child. You do you, but I DO have something to brag about since you wanted to bring it up.

And by the way for anyone wondering, the info for teaching preschool children how to read and write and number manipulation is ALL ONLINE. The info is majority free. The tools available to parents today are absolutely insane. But please, google the avg parents daily hrs of instagram and Facebook usage and get back to me.

29.author: tebanano
29.body:
So which one is it? Do you work 50+ hours or do you spend an enormous amount of time with your kids? They’re kinda mutually exclusive unless you’re working at night. Or can I assume that your wife did most of this work?

To be clear, I don’t give a fuck about the academic achievements of your toddlers. There’s evidence that focusing on academic performance on toddlers is either pointless or even detrimental on the long run. This is beside the point, though: the point is you are pontificating while riding a high horse, painting yourself as perfect and judging moms for wanting to work.

29.author: stonky808
29.body:
No I’m judging ANYONE who chooses to work over taking care of their baby/child if they don’t have to. YOU are the one who keeps accusing me of saying things that I am not. Taking an hour or two a day to work on you young child’s learning pays dividends. It blows your mind I can work 8 hrs a day 6 days a week and still have time for my kids? Blows your mind I can work 8 hrs a day 5 days a week and 16 hrs on the 6th day? I’m not sitting on any high horse….im pointing out how tons of parents make excuses for bs priorities.

Regardless of what “evidence” you have, my children being taught phonetic decoding and math games from when they were young has put all of them in the 90%+ percentile amongst all their peers.

29.author: tebanano
29.body:
You started this rant against mothers who took their kids to daycare because they “wanted a career” when you obviously kept your career.  Then you moved the goal post and it was against the ones who “will not give up or reduce their hours” when you obviously did it do that either. Then again you moved the goal post to some demonized caricature of the “average parent”

I’m sorry, but “an hour or two” is not an “enormous amount of time” with your children, so which one is it? So which one is it? Do you work 50+ hours or do you spend an enormous amount of time with your kids? Or are you gonna admit your wife does most of the work?

PS: p90 of bullshit is still bullshit.

29.author: stonky808
29.body:
I said I would GLADLY give up my career if my wife wanted to be a career woman and me a stay at home dad, so I don’t know wtf you are talking about. 

And an hour or two of phonetic decoding and writing at 3 years old is a ton of time. Now you gonna try and convince me it’s common lmao. I work 50 hrs and like I have said I’ve spent an enormous amount of time with my kids. Let me clarify…..enormous amount of time TEACHING my kids. Time in general? WAY less than my wife, she’s the primary caretaker and is there from the moment they get out of bed to the time they go to bed.

Women get salty asf every time this subject comes up lol. Shame on them feeling entitled that they DESERVE a career and toss their babies into daycare EVEN IF THEY DONT HAVE TO.

29.author: tebanano
29.body:
> I said I would GLADLY give up my career 

Talk is cheap. You talk the talk but don’t walk the walk, and on top of that, you judge women for making the exact same choices as you: not giving up their careers and not reducing their work hours and only spending 2 hours a day with their kids. 

On the plus side, you’re finally giving your wife the credit she deserves. If anyone can brag about the kids, it’s her.

29.author: stonky808
29.body: Um between the two of us, one doesn’t work so someone can always be with the kids. That’s better than BOTH being gone is is that hard to understand. Your just another woman getting triggered because facts and logic make you angry. Also I work 6am to 2pm…..im home before they get off of school. Nice try though.

29.author: tebanano
29.body:
> Your just another woman getting triggered because facts and logic make you angry.

That’s me alright, all woman, all the time. From the tip of my toes to the tip of my penis.

You already acknowledged your wife does the bulk of the work, and that you do exactly the same things you criticize others for. Hope you’re kinder to your wife than you are to other moms.

29.author: stonky808
29.body: Bull of what WORK? She works 20 hrs a week or none at all. That’s the bull of work to you? Lol. And for the 100th time, I’m criticizing parents who BOTH work when they don’t have to….literally how many times do I have to say it? LITERALLY HOW MANY TIMES?!

29.author: tebanano
29.body:
> she’s the primary caretaker and is there from the moment they get out of bed to the time they go to bed.

Sounds way more than 20 hours, unless you don’t consider that work.

29.author: stonky808
29.body:
Way more than 20 hrs? Of course. But all of our children are in school. Want to know what my wife does while the kids are in school? Whatever tf her heart desires. 

I’m sorry you are so triggered that you need to nitpick on nonsense. Truth hurts sometimes.

30.author: randylahey2883
30.body: I did at 23. Even during those first few years, it wasn’t as stressful as things are now. Our careers (even though we’re paid well) cause us a lot of stress. I just remember being young even though we were poor, were way less stressed. Maybe because we we’re starting a new exciting chapter in our life

30.author: vianiznice
30.body:
Glad to hear you're moving along!

Personally I didn't find peace until I hit my early 30s.

30.author: vianiznice
30.body:
Self reliance came as a shock at first, but that's not the reason.

I fought with depression and anxiety all through out my 20s.

30.author: randylahey2883
30.body: This is sort of what I’m going through my late 30’s

30.author: vianiznice
30.body:
I wish you all the best. From personal experience, anxiety is fake fears, don't let them govern your day.

Exposure "therapy" was the way out for me.

31.author: AnimalFew491
31.body: No, people have lives and different track mind, dont take it offensive or "ghosted" shes just living

31.author: KarmaInFlow
31.body: The definition of ghosting is someone putting in the effort, then no longer putting in any effort. Aka exactly what op described.

31.author: KarmaInFlow
31.body: Its called ghosting why must you be stubborn

31.author: AnimalFew491
31.body: Its not 'ghosting' its 'people taking sh*t personal'

32.author: Watson_A_Name
32.body: I see it's more nuanced than. Thanks for explaining.

32.author: BecauseWhyNotTakeTwo
32.body:
As a proportion there are actually more women's shelters than general shelters.

And all domestic violence shelters are for women, despite men representing about half of all victims.

32.author: Watson_A_Name
32.body: I agree. I'm just saying the first step in any hypothetical change would be to acknowledge that certain things are also men's issues, AND that men have unique issues that we need addressed which are completely ignored. THAT would be why it matters, in my opinion.

33.author: Fantastic-Ninja-8323
33.body: I brought it up to my gf and she brought up that this phrase is a glass half full or half empty situation. It depends on your assumed expectations of the person you’re talking to, which I presume you had as negative and I assumed were positive

33.author: YamDelicious651
33.body:
No. “I underestimated you “= you exceeded my expectations 
“I could never underestimate you”= no matter what expectation I set you would no ever exceed it=  I could set no expectation and would not underestimate you . Could also be used as I could never underestimate you as in I will always think you can do it The reverse “ I could never overestimate you “ can also be used as in : I could never have a higher expectation of you because my expectations are non existent but could also mean you would always rise to the occasion no matter if they are sky high . Tonality here is key as both can be interpreted in a positive light hence a failed insult which is the worst possible failure in my estimation assuming that it’s correct

33.author: Fantastic-Ninja-8323
33.body: But yes now I understand that it can be an insult but it can also be a compliment too, that’s the beauty of it

33.author: Fantastic-Ninja-8323
33.body:
I underestimate you ≠ I underestimated you. Because of the implications. I understand that the first one implies the actual meaning, think less than they are actually capable of, and the second implies the opposite, that those expectations are exceeded. Yes, I understand your logic, but no this phrase is not discreetly an insult. That’s what makes it so good, it is open to interpretation. 
I could never overestimate you is in the same boat, it implies you go into the situation with negative expectations but it is dependent on the context. Whether it is before or after said event that alters expectations

34.author: techsldr

Please explain.

34.author: imbecile

So you don't know what you want, what you wanna do?

Well, that certainly explains a lot about the vapidity and aimlessness in the chatter of a lot of people.

34.author: techsldr
34.body:
Pardon me, I am still failing to understand you.

What will i wanna do while talking to friends?

34.author: imbecile
34.body: So you don't wanna enjoy yourself and engage your friends when you are with them and nothing else is up?

34.author: techsldr
34.body:
I do, I do... I am not a native english speaker, so apologies for your trouble...

I got your point, and it is a great one. Thank you

Marriage is no more boring/exciting than single life; as in it depends on the person

35.author: jackwritespecs

Is what it is.

36.author: forever5y
36.body: I agree they are equals.  I disagree, everyone deserves to be respected.  It's not the intent it's the actions that really matter.

36.author: lakelurnia
36.body: If you simultaneously describe men as special, precious, and valuable, then I am 100% with you ;)

36.author: forever5y
36.body:
Everyone should be treated this way regardless of gender.  

This was told to me as a young man starting to explore dating.  Advice given to start me on a path of how I should view the women in my life.  It created a balance that I have kept all these years.
